title: A Guide to Bivariate Table 1
text: starting tutorial, want thank developers packages table1 (Benjamin Rich), flextable (David Gohel Colleagues). Really credit go teams maintaining two packages.Full disclosure: function merely provides easy--use API wrapper around packages get beautiful publication-ready bivariate comparison table 1. Creating descriptive sociodemographic table can tedious repetitive task. Every published article table (usually first, table1). However, found frustrated amount work took create table, especially repetitive task, always believed easy solution R. Recently discovered table1::table1() function, made life much easier. advanced example given Benjamin Rich combined ability flextable::flextable() get nicely formatted Word. talking , might think? See ; just requires one function call! Characteristic Healthy Controls(N = 52) Breast Cancer Patients(N = 64) t / χ² df p Fictional Smoking Status     .499 ͣ   Non-Smoker 31 (60 %) 33 (52 %)      Occasionally 0 (0 %) 2 (3 %)      Smoker 21 (40 %) 29 (45 %)    Glucose *** 88 (± 10) 110 (± 27) -4.8 84.48 < .001 Insulin ** 6.9 (± 4.9) 13 (± 12) -3.32 85.57 .0013 Leptin 27 (± 19) 27 (± 19) 0.01 114 .991 Age 58 (± 19) 57 (± 13) 0.45 89.37 .654 BMI 28 (± 5.4) 27 (± 4.6) 1.43 114 .156 Note. Differences determined independent sample t-test Pearson's χ²-test. ͣ Fisher's exact test, expected cell-count ≤ 1. published articles, kind table () usually first table (thus called Table 1). example shows descriptive stats two subgroups sample (aka bivariate descriptive). function also automatically conducts group comparisons (, desired, corrects) obtained p-values. metric/interval data: independent sample t-test case heterogeneity variances Welch’s correction applied categorical/ordinal data: Pearon’s χ²-test respective Fisher's test expected cell counts ≤ 5). show can create table get Word just basic simple steps.

previous_headings: Step by Step Tutorial > 1.) Data and Setup
title: A Guide to Bivariate Table 1
text: Now, demonstration purposes, slightly modify original data set. start changing column Classification factor assigning correct labels, obtained UCI repository.: Additionally generate new fictional variable called random_Smoking 3 associated factor levels c("Smoker","Non-Smoker","Occasionally"). Please note part original data just fabricated illustrate utility flex_table1() function comparison factors.
code: | Labels: | 1=Healthy controls | 2=Patients # Modify the Data breast_cancer_modified <- breast_cancer %>%   # Create a Factor Variable from Classification Column   # And add Labels to the Factor Levels   mutate(Diagnosis = factor(Classification,     labels = c("Healthy Controls", "Breast Cancer Patients")   )) %>%   # Remove the old Variable   select(-Classification) %>%   # Generate a New Fictional Categorical Variable: random_Smoking   mutate(random_Smoking = sample(c("Smoker", "Non-Smoker", "Occasionally"),     size = nrow(breast_cancer),     replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.49, 0.49, 0.02)   )) %>%   # Convert the Randomly Generated Variable into a Factor   mutate(random_Smoking = factor(random_Smoking))  # Giving the new fictional column a name to be shown in the table var_label(breast_cancer_modified$random_Smoking) <- "Fictional Smoking Status"

what: 3.) Creation of Bivariate Table 1 Including Comparisons
title: A Guide to Bivariate Table 1
text: function datscience::flex_table1 provides nice API creating Table 1 bivariate group comparison. two mandatory arguments: data = data.frame use, example use previously prepared modified breast cancer data data = breast_cancer_modified Glucose, Insulin, Leptin, Age BMI sample, Additionally fictional smoking status differs Cancer Patients Healthy Controls formula string look like : "~ random_Smoking  + Glucose + Insulin + Leptin +Age + BMI|Diagnosis" tutorial also add caption table. ’s . included function call argument ref_correction = TRUE marks p-values respective correction applied. However TRUE also default value. change behavior just passing FALSE Creation Table Table 4 Sample Characteristics, Comparison Healthy Controls Cancer Patients. Characteristic Healthy Controls(N = 52) Breast Cancer Patients(N = 64) t / χ² df p Fictional Smoking Status     .499 ͣ   Non-Smoker 31 (60 %) 33 (52 %)      Occasionally 0 (0 %) 2 (3 %)      Smoker 21 (40 %) 29 (45 %)    Glucose *** 88 (± 10) 110 (± 27) -4.8 84.48 < .001 Insulin ** 6.9 (± 4.9) 13 (± 12) -3.32 85.57 .0013 Leptin 27 (± 19) 27 (± 19) 0.01 114 .991 Age 58 (± 19) 57 (± 13) 0.45 89.37 .654 BMI 28 (± 5.4) 27 (± 4.6) 1.43 114 .156 Note. Differences determined independent sample t-test Pearson's χ²-test. ͣ Fisher's exact test, expected cell-count ≤ 1.
code: flex_table1(   str_formula = "~ random_Smoking  + Glucose + Insulin + Leptin +Age + BMI|Diagnosis",    data = breast_cancer_modified,   table_caption = c(     "Table 4",     "Sample Characteristics, Comparison of Healthy Controls and Cancer Patients."   ),   ref_correction = TRUE )%>%   # Only For markdown we additionally need to fix the autofit property, this step is not   # needed when directly saved to word e.g. with datscience::save_flextable()   set_table_properties(layout = "autofit", width = 1)

title: Dataanalysis and Science Utility Functions
text: flextable package versatile exactly looking get nicely formatted tables directly R(studio) Word. holds true datscience::format_flextable() function datscience package. just applies repetitive formatting necessary convert flextable “publication ready” APA formatted table. One example flexibility just try print factor loadings prinicipal component analysis (PCA, psych::prinicial) Let’s first create exemplary PCA[1, 2]extract factor loadings: (also conveniently packaged function apa_factorLoadings() function) Formatting loadings APA just one function:
code: # Creation of an Example Prinicipal Component Analysis pacman::p_load(psych, dplyr) pc <- principal(Harman74.cor$cov, 4, rotate = "varimax") pc_loadings <- pc %>%   fa.sort() %>%   .[["loadings"]] %>%   round(3) %>%   unclass() %>%   as.data.frame() %>%   mutate(across(     everything(),     ~ if_else((. < 0.3), "", as.character(.))   )) %>%   bind_cols(     Communality = pc$communality,     Uniqueness = pc$uniquenesses,     Complexity = pc$complexity   ) %>%   mutate(across(where(is.numeric), round, 2)) %>%   tibble::rownames_to_column("items") formatted_loadings <- datscience::format_flextable(flextable::flextable(pc_loadings),   table_caption = c("Table 3", "Factor Loadings in Exemplary PCA") ) formatted_loadings

what: Create APA Publication Ready Correlation Table and Export to Word or Powerpoint — apa_corrTable
title: Create APA Publication Ready Correlation Table and Export to Word or Powerpoint — apa_corrTable
text: Idea inspired blog post colleague Remi Theriault (see remi-theriault.com) utilized ability flextable able get APA-style formatted table directly R .docx (word). One frequent use case get correlation table word. creation correlation table function uses corstars function package, resolves around code Dominik Vogel. built idea created function creates pretty correlation table together summary stats choice, returns flextable, can easily exported word (see also  save_flextable)Please note: function considers numeric variables (cols). datatypes dropped data.frame df. interaction arguments sig.level nod. sig.level set NA, improves formatting decimals places finale table, removes stars marking significance. However, also prevents table differing number decimal places. Meaning number decimals correlation also determine number decimals summary statistics

title: Create APA Publication Ready Correlation Table and Export to Word or Powerpoint — apa_corrTable
code: apa_corrTable(   df,   summarystats = c("mean", "sd"),   method = c("pearson", "spearman", "polychoric"),   rmDiag = FALSE,   sig.level = 0.05,   nod = c(2, -1),   filepath = NA,   overwrite = FALSE,   ... )

title: Create APA Publication Ready Correlation Table and Export to Word or Powerpoint — apa_corrTable
text: df Data.frame, mandatory argument. Consider filtering passing e.g. dplyr::select() dplyr::filter() summarystats vector summary stats included bottom correlation.  Default c("mean","sd") Options one c("mean","sd","median","range","min","max","skew", "kurtosis","se","missing"). option "missing", adds missings per item additional row (accecpts "missing" "missings", spelling table accordingly). NA given, summarystats added. method Type correlation. Options currently: "pearson", "spearman" "polychoric" rmDiag diagonal corr matrix kept (FALSE) removed (TRUE) sig.level many stars per level significance, options include .05 .01 .001. NA stars indicating significance output. improves formatting decimals table. Note default polychoric NA nod (Optional) Integer Integer Vector. Number Decimals. case -1 simple convention based sample size applied determination number decimal points. See get_number_of_decimals. can also provide Integer vector, want different number decimals correlations summary stats. first integer determines nod correlations, second summary stats. E.g., nod = c(2,-1) give 2 decimals correlations apply convention summary stats. Default nod = c(2,-1).  See get_number_of_decimals ?datscience::get_number_of_decimals filepath (Optional) Path filename APA ready table saved, options include common filetypes .docx (Word), .pptx (Powerpoint), .html (Webpage). Default filepath = NA. NA given, file saved. overwrite (Optional) Boolean, default FALSE. overwrite FALSE files already exists, serialized version filename created (.e., appending _001, _002). Utilizes serialNext ... (Optional), Additional arguments can passed format_flextable (e.g., fontsize, font ...) serialNext

title: Create an APA Formatted Table of Factor Loadings — apa_factorLoadings
text: fa_object Either fa principal, factor loadings extracted filepath (Optional) Path filename APA ready table saved, options include common filetypes .docx (Word), .pptx (Powerpoint), .html (Webpage). Default filepath = NA. NA given, file saved. table_caption Takes character vector. Recommend following elements Table + number (e.g., "Table 3") description, use APA capital case (e.g., "PCA / EFA Factor Loadings") overwrite (Optional) Boolean, default FALSE. overwrite FALSE files already exists, serialized version filename created (.e., appending _001, _002). Utilizes serialNext nod (Optional) Integer Integer Vector. Number Decimals. case -1 simple convention based sample size applied determination number decimal points. See ?datscience::get_number_of_decimals. can also provide Integer vector, want different number decimals correlations summary stats. first integer determines nod factor loadings, second additional stats. E.g., c(2,-1) give 2 decimals factor loadings apply convention Complexity, Uniqueness Communality. Default nod = c(3,2).  See get_number_of_decimals ?datscience::get_number_of_decimals n.obs (Optional), required want apply convention number decimals, calculate factor analysis (PCA, EFA) directly correlation covariance matrix. cutoff (Optional), Integer, determines minimum threshold, values omitted. Default cutoff = 0.3. orderbyloading (Optional), Boolean, default orderbyloading = TRUE. TRUE, items table sorted loading first factor / component (convention). use cases, rather want maintain ordering used conduct analysis (e.g., alphabetical). can archieve providing orderbyloading = FALSE ... (Optional), Additional arguments can passed format_flextable (e.g., fontsize, font ...) serialNext

title: Creates a Descriptive Bivariate Table1 Ready for Publication — flex_table1
text: Fisher's Exact Test (FET) vs Pearson's χ²-test      Newest feature (07/22), according excellent post cross-validated (Harrell 2011)      function refrains using Fisher's exact test (FET) categorical     variables applies FET rare case cells expected     cell frequencies exceed 1. due fact, FET can     extreme ressource intensive (slow), can type error rates less     nominal level (Crans Shuster 2008)      Contemporary evidence suggests, Pearson s χ²-test     modification \(\frac{N-1}{N}\), nearly allways accurate FET     generally recommended (Lydersen et al. 2009) . Thus     accordance use N-1 Pearson χ²-test proposed (E.) Pearson recommended     optimum test policy (Campbell 2007) . Multiple Comparisons      Let start direct quote     "(..) researchers automatically (mindlessly)     assume alpha adjustment necessary multiple testing."     (Rubin 2021)      Whether, correct multiple comparison inferential statistic,     still area ongoing debate. However recently argued     essential differentiate different forms multiple comparisons,     make decision correction (Rubin 2021) .     types multiple testing : disjunction testing conjunction testing individual testing Please refer well written laid original publication     details. use case function, one can assume     joint null hypotheses, Group <...> Group N differ.     Now example, sufficient groups differ significantly     one characteristic, considered disjunction testing.     However, interested constituent (null-)hypotheses (e.g.,     groups differ highest level education vs. differ current     employment status), categorized individual testing.     Please chose considerately individual case.     However typical exploratory     bivariate comparison sociodemographic table1, deem frequently     cases individual testing, thus flex_table1() function defaults     applying correction.

title: Creates a Descriptive Bivariate Table1 Ready for Publication — flex_table1
text: Bjoern Buedenbender, Imports & Name Space

title: Creates a Descriptive Bivariate Table1 Ready for Publication — flex_table1
code: if (FALSE) {   # Comparison of just two Groups    str_formula <- "~ Sepal.Length + Sepal.Width +test | Species"    data <- dplyr::filter(iris, Species %in% c("setosa", "versicolor"))    data$test <- factor(rep(c("Female", "Male"), 50))    table_caption <- c("Table 1", "A test on the Iris Data")    flex_table1(str_formula, data = data, table_caption = table_caption)    # Comparison of Multiple Groups (ANOVA)    str_formula <- "~ Sepal.Length + Sepal.Width + Gender_example | Species"    data <- dplyr::filter(iris, Species %in% c("setosa", "versicolor"))    data <- iris    data$Gender_example <- factor(rep(c("Female", "Male"), nrow(data)/2))    table_caption <- c("Table 1", "A test on the Iris Data")    flex_table1(str_formula, data = data, table_caption = table_caption)    }

what: Conduct a comparison for independent sample means - either t-test or one-way ANOVA — independent_sample_means
title: Conduct a comparison for independent sample means - either t-test or one-way ANOVA — independent_sample_means
text: convenience function, provides easy use wrapper step--step comparison means independent groups. steps run analysis : 0. Determination groups 2 groups conduct independent sample t-test. 2 groups ANOVA conducted instead 1. Detect outliers extreme values including boxplots identify values. Utilizes identify_outliers 2. Calculate descriptive statistics groups, self-explanatory. 3. Check normal distribution (assumptions) uses formal test (Shapiro-Wilk) well visual inspection method (qqplots). Carefully judge step, function default handling non-normality. Options include check literature test scenario robust violations (see also central limit theorem Glass, 1972), switch non-parametric alternative. 4. Check homogeneity variances (assumption) purpose levene test conducted. significant (convention p < .05) result indicates H0 (equal variances) must disregarded. Depending result student t-test pooled variance / "normal" ANOVA used. heterogeneity variances (.e., unequal variances) Welch correction degrees freedom used instead. 5. test (t-Test ANOVA) conducted, including Post-Hoc Comparisons calculation effect size. Additionally ggpubr package used together rstatix display Boxplot including result hypothesis test. function mere wrapper excellent tutorials provided Alboukadel Kassambara Datanovia. See original Guide t-test ANOVA. just packages steps one function convenience

title: pretty_cm - Pretty Caret Confusion Matrices — pretty_cm

Default: TRUE

title: Swaps labels and col names from a .sav (SPSS) matrix — spss_swap
text: many situations can useful ability replace uninformative variable names (colnames) SPSS matrix (e.g. SD02, SD08_02) respective label attribute (e.g., "Gender/Sex" "Age 15-25"). function utilizes utility function clean_names convert labels SPSS proper variable names (e.g.,"gender_sex" "age_15_25") sets new column names

title: Swaps labels and col names from a .sav (SPSS) matrix — spss_swap
text: df tibble read read_sav haven repl_umlaut Default TRUE. provided True replaces umlauts (vowel mutations) like ä, ö, ü ß respective ae, oe, ue, ss old_itemnames Options "prepend", "append" , "remove". Default "prepend" "prepend" new item names prepended old item names. E.g., old item name "q0003" description "Gender" new item name "q0003_gender"
